1.text:
Alice: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English.
I'm Alice.

5.text:
Alice: So Rob, what job did you want to do
when you were little?

8.text:
Rob: I really wanted to be an astronaut. Be
in orbit, watching the Earth from afar...

14.text:
Alice: Wow! Be in orbit - it means be in space
and following the Earth's curvature.

20.text: Well, the view must be nice from up there.

22.text:
But the reality of becoming an astronaut is
pretty hard.

26.text: And it's the subject of today's show!

29.text:
Did you know that less than 600 people have
been into space so far?

33.text:
Rob: I'd like to have been one of them. I
know I have what it takes to be a spaceman!

38.text:
Alice: Yes. There are many others like you
who would like to go for this job, Rob.

42.text: And that's the quiz question for you today.

45.text:
How many people have applied to join Nasa's
2017 astronaut class? Was it...

59.text:
Rob: Mmmm... 8,000 sounds like a lot already
so I'll go for b) 8,000 people.

65.text:
Alice: Well, we'll find out if you chose the
right answer later on in the programme.

69.text:
So, what do you think is the biggest challenge
when considering becoming an astronaut?

74.text:
Rob: Well, I'd say claustrophobia ... and
that means: fear of being in a small space.

80.text:
That might be a problem because the space
capsules are small and you're with the same

85.text: people for months at a time.

87.text:
Alice: Yes, that's right. Well, astronauts
are bound to get on each other's nerves sometimes!

92.text:
To get on someone's nerves means: to annoy
them.

95.text:
Rob: But I'm a great team player... so I think
I'll be OK.

99.text:
Alice: Yes, I can confirm that. Anyway, the
challenge of being an astronaut doesn't stop here.

105.text:
In the space capsule, astronauts have to put
up with extremely difficult conditions.

112.text:
Rob: It looks like doing somersaults in the
capsule and catching bits of food in your

116.text: mouth as it floats out of its packet.

118.text:
Alice: But zero gravity – a condition where
gravity is exerting no force

124.text: can lead to wasting of the bones and muscles.

127.text:
Astronauts take two and a half hours of exercise
per day to help prevent this.

131.text:
Rob: But what do astronauts have to do before
they go into space to prepare themselves for

138.text:
Alice: They can practice using a virtual reality
headset and special gloves.

143.text:
It's like playing a computer game that looks
and feels like doing a spacewalk.

147.text: And they also train in a swimming pool!

151.text:
Let's listen to Major Tim Peake, a British
astronaut,

154.text:
talking about the preparation he did for his
mission on the International Space Station.

159.text:
Major Tim Peake: The way we practise spacewalk
is in water.

162.text:
Water gives us the neutral buoyancy that we
need.

164.text:
So we sink training modules into swimming
pools and then practise the spacewalking on them.

169.text:
We wear very specific equipment, a pressurized
spacesuit – very difficult to move in actually

174.text: it's hard to bend the fingers, it's hard to bend your arms ... and it really gives you quite a difficult workout.

180.text:
Rob: British astronaut Tim Peake says water
gives us buoyancy, which is the ability to float.

186.text: Floating in space is similar to floating in water, so astronauts practise their spacewalk in swimming pools.

192.text:
Alice: Yes. They take to the water and to
the air too.

196.text:
Astronauts experience the feeling of weightlessness
in planes.

200.text:
A large plane with padded walls flies to high
altitude and then goes into a nosedive

206.text:
Or a fast and sudden fall which creates short
periods of weightlessness.

211.text: Rob: Fabulous! I'd love to do that!

213.text: Alice: But it's not all fun and games.

216.text:
Don't forget that one of the main reasons
for being out on the International Space Station

222.text:
Major Tim Peake is doing scientific experiments
such as how to grow plants in space,

227.text:
and what effect radiation and zero gravity
have on this process.

231.text: Rob: Like that film where an astronaut gets stranded ... or left behind on Mars and has to grow potatoes.

237.text: Rob: The film is called The Martian.

239.text: Alice: That's right. Yes. So do you think you have what it takes to survive in a challenging environment, Rob?

245.text:
Let's listen to Major Tim Peake talking about
his survival training.

249.text:
Major Tim Peak: Survival training: for this
year the European Space Agency sends us to Sardinia.

253.text:
When you land in the Soyuz capsule sometimes
you might not land exactly where you expect to be.

258.text:
Foraging for food, for example, and your basic
elements of shelter and protection, getting water...

263.text:
Go and live in a cave for seven days with
an international crew.

266.text:
And it's a wonderful environment to prepare
you for a mission because you are very isolated.

272.text: Rob: So astronauts may get stranded on Earth

275.text: when the space capsule lands somewhere unexpected.

277.text:
And they have to find food. Forage means to
search.

280.text:
Alice: It's a word we often use to describe
how animals search for food.

284.text:
Rob: Indeed. Well, let's go back to that quiz
question you asked me earlier, Alice.

289.text:
I'm keen to know how many people want to live
this experience of being an astronaut.

294.text:
Alice: OK. Well, I asked: How many people
have applied to join NASA's 2017 astronaut class?

302.text: Was it... a) 800, b) 8,000 or c) 18,000 people?

310.text: Rob: And I said quite a lot: b) 8,000 people.

314.text: Alice: And you were wrong, I'm afraid!

317.text:
According to Nasa's website, more than 18,300
people applied to join their 2017 astronaut class.

324.text:
This is almost three times the number of applications
received in 2012 for the most recent astronaut class.

330.text:
Rob: Wow! So there's no chance of me ever
succeeding.

333.text: Alice: Oh, well, you mustn't give up, Rob.

335.text:
Anyway, we are running out of time so here
are the words we heard today:

353.text:
Rob: Well, that's the end of today's 6 Minute
English. Please join us again soon!
